job_title: Administrative Coordinator in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Family-like culture, students come first.
cons: None at this time - a very fair place to work.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Saint Paul, MN
pros: - Good Pay - Great Benefits - Rewarding Job - Good Work Life Balance Pro/Con - Having a good team makes all the difference, your manager sets the tone for how things are done. If interviewing see if you can talk to some of the team one on one.
cons: - Work Environment is very different on campus vs online

pros: Very little micromanaging from direct reports.
cons: The company makes abrupt changes that affect staff faulty and most importantly the students. They implement the ch ages often times without warming or time for messaging to go out.

pros: Decent out of college starting salary $0.25 soda machine That's literally all I can think of!
cons: Horrid horrid management style at the company. Cut throat aggressive cold calling is your daily task. Your teammates can steal your contacts if step away from your desk for instance. Management does not care about you and you are simply replaceable. You are constantly being watched by management and have 3-4 meetings a week with them. Also when the online classes start you are expected to not take any vacation time off the week before and the week of classes beginning; with 8 start dates a year that means around 16 weeks out of the year you can kiss your time off bye bye. At the end of the day you are pushing student loans on to people who are not ready for college, and the school will even make exceptions to extend deadlines so they get the student loan money!

review_title: Run, don’t walk away from this incompetent employer
pros: Remote work was made available when the pandemic began
cons: For the amount of work that needs to be completed, the pay is garbage. Mid-level management is even worse. C level executives have been leaving one by one.

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Good time off, tuition benefits if you want
cons: Micro managed, sales driven, call quotas

job_title: Admissions Advisor in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Are there any? None ???
cons: The grind never stops. Constantly recruiting in admissions. Low reviews. High turnover rate.

pros: It is a great company that is continuously growing. Giving plenty of opportunity for employees to grow as well. Great environment and you may have your own students to enroll, but you still have assistance from your team.
cons: Wish the pay were a little higher since you can not make commission off enrollments.

pros: Nice coworkers Good benefits Good hours
cons: Not a lot of opportunity for growth.

job_title: Academic Advisor in Green Bay, WI
pros: benefits, work from home, culture
cons: limited advancement opportunities at this level

pros: I worked for Rasmussen for more than 14 years. It allowed me an opportunity to grow professionally, meet absolutely incredible people and support my family with decent pay. I was also able to continue my education and earned a Master's degree at a discounted price through one of the affiliated partners.
cons: Terrible leadership. Leadership micro-manages basically down to the second of each day. Employees (although all college educated and many with YEARS of admissions experience) are not trusted to perform basic tasks and constantly second guessed. The common theme of every meeting is "more more more". There is no reward system for good performance, instead all employees are given the same raise even though some produce much higher results. Leadership repeatedly says they are "transparent" while never being forth coming with changes within the organization.

pros: You have a lot of freedom in how you structure your classes.
cons: The University as an organization is very unorganized.

job_title: Senior Accountant in Oak Brook, IL
pros: a few good co workers
cons: working on weekends for close

pros: The salary is higher than other schools.
cons:
Too focused on growth. They havnt mastered previous projects before venturing into new ones like opening new campuses, new programs, etc. 
No quality control from top to bottom. Those who care about the quality simply dont have the time to do what it takes to get it right. 
Almost all of the nursing campuses have outgrown the room needed so many instructors have to work evenings teaching. 
You never get a break. You will have to take your work with you on vacations. I was told "you can buy the internet package" when going on a cruise during our scheduled week off. The same was said we we tried to vacation out of country.
You are met with very passive aggressive management when you want to take personal time. You cant just take days off because you are always scheduled with students and there arent "extra" instructors floating around to teach for you when you are gone. 
This job is great for the following people: workaholics, single individuals who want their life to be their work, people who absolutely dont want to work at the bedside and will tolerate a school with no value on education. Their statements say they care about the quality of student's education but their actions really never show the same.
As an instructor there is no room for growth. The next step up is associate dean which means you will work minimum 70 hours a week. You end up making less per hour than you did before. Our deans have no time for us. For the last 3 years most meetings I've had with my dean have been rescheduled because shes too late or they have her in another meeting that is "more important". I once had a meeting rescheduled 4 times and each time I was actually there waiting for her to show up and she popped in several minutes after the meeting time and said we had to reschedule. That kind of stuff makes you feel incredibly important as a faculty member.
Across all 25+ nursing campuses their NCLEX pass rates have been in decline for a few years and the outlook is grim. They are close to being on probation and losing their accreditation.

pros: Remote work is a nice benefit
cons: Care about bottom line only

pros: There is great Flexibility available
cons: Lots of paper work to do

pros: Small team, great organization and helpful environment
cons: High enrollment metrics, no opportunity for overtime and strict blackout dates

pros:
- Great Student Advisors
- Amazing resources for students 
- Great professional development for staff
cons: Organization and transitions needs improvement

pros: Coworkers were helpful but somewhat aloof
cons: In one year, there were three different deans. It was my first teaching job and I was given a binder and the dean said "Good luck!". Not ideal.

job_title: IT Work Study in Rockford, IL
pros: Great work place with the ability to study and learn more
cons: There was no Cons that I encountered.

pros:
Coworkers are friendly
Compensation is fair
cons: Misleading job title. Program manager is a full time recruiter.

pros: Good teamwork, hands on experience, interaction with students
cons: Disorganized at times, travel requirements

pros: None. This University is 1 accreditation short of a diploma mill
cons: It is simply criminal what they do to these students. They over fill the classes and hope they have the faculty to teach them. Spoiler alert, they don’t. They hire any willing body, experience or not, to be a figure head to “teach”. The campus is riddled with incompetence and LAZY instructors. The students absolutely suffer and basically teach themselves. Criminal!!

pros: Adaptable and willing to make changes to capture an ever-evolving market place.
cons: Nothing that I can think of.

pros:
- Flexible schedules
- Management is awesome
- Work-life balance
cons:

- Burnout

review_title: Fellow Faculty were great, Leadership was a joke
pros: The faculty I worked with were amazing. I was brand new and I was accepted and pushed to be the best I could be.
cons: I was lied to so many times and I would find out about the lies from Coworkers not Leadership

pros: East going for pt teaching work. No huge raises, but a good side gig.
cons: Not many if any pay raises. Low pay

job_title: Dean of Nursing in Pasco, FL
pros: Excellent students outcomes, fully accredited.
cons: Nursing school is difficult for students working fulltime

pros: Flexibility, great culture, competitive salaries, great benefits
cons: there are seasons that the hours can be long.

job_title: Support Specialist in Brooklyn Park, MN
pros:
- Great Student Advisors and Deans
- Organized Faculty and Instructors
- Ton of resources for students and alumni
- Yearly pay increase 
- Promotion from within 
- Transparent and inclusive environment
cons:

- Lack of preparing students for fast pace programs (students easily become overloaded depending on what program they are in)

pros: Good coworkers who care about students
cons: Poor management, poor direct management

pros: Friendly faculty and staff! Flexible schedule and willing to help. Always willing to help out
cons: None that come to mind. Really enjoyed the environment. Friendly faculty and staff! Flexible schedule and willing to help. Always willing to help out

review_title: An awesome start to a career
pros: I love who I work with and what I do
cons: It's not enough to live on by yourself in the area of living

job_title: Talent Acquisition Specialist in Bloomington, MN
pros: Work life balance, autonomy, remote work, culture
cons: Lower pay, so so benefits

pros: Salary is above average for nurse faculty.
cons: Quarter system, lack of consistency, lack of communication

pros: Great people, helping students, work-life balance
cons: Hard to Advance or get promoted

pros: Experience, Helping other students, Great Team
cons: Part time work and temporary

pros: Good benefits and people to work with
cons: Not really any cons to put here

job_title: Fulltime Nursing Faculty in Bloomington, MN
pros: Built in time off after each quarter, some schedule flexibility, good coworkers, curriculum provided
cons: No pto accrual, working far over 40 hours each week, no prep or grading time built into faculty schedule, no orientation or training, student population

job_title: Instructional Designer in Oak Brook, IL
pros: Work remotely allows for better work-life balance.
cons: Nothing specific comes to mind.

review_title: Good people, but unrealistic job expectations.
job_title: Transfer Credit Specialist in Bloomington, MN
pros: Great people, good benefits package.
cons: Unrealistic expectations of workload, hard to keep up without getting overwhelmed.

job_title: Senior Admissions Advisor in Bloomington, MN
pros: Family environment and great culture
cons: Weekend and evening hours required

job_title: Learning And Development Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I have learned and grew professionally and personally through the working experience at Rasmussen.
cons: Negative perceptions of the college, due to its for profit status , is far from the reality. The college always puts students at the core of everything we do.

pros: Great non-monetary incentives, ability to truly advocate for students AND college policies. Excellent management support at this location.
cons: Competition with other campuses fuels lack of true sharing successful strategies to help students succeed.

pros: WFH, great team, great supervisor
cons: Occasional demanding students can be stressful.

pros: Salary, benefits and supportive administration
cons: Online teaching can be difficult

pros: It's a great place to work. Flexible allowed to work from home durring pandemic.
cons: No cons that I can think of

pros: The people are positive and nice. Supportive management
cons: Heavy workload for full time faculty

review_title: Declining morale, limited opportunities for growth
pros: Compensation is above average in admissions. Work-life balance is valued as many positions are required to work 40 hour work weeks. Rasmussen College is making an effort to make private-for-profit college more affordable. It is satisfying to help change lives through education. The college does not cut corners on accreditation and I have no doubt that a degree from Rasmussen will benefit the prospective students I talk to.
cons:
Company lacks a competitive identity and vision for growth. "Vertical" organizational structure is poorly executed. Poor messaging and lack of communication causes unnecessary conflict between departments. 
This is not a happy place to work anymore. Company-wide layoffs are becoming the norm, year after year. Morale/productivity is declining as many employees are worried about losing their jobs as student resources are consolidated and centralized. As departments shrink, opportunities for professional growth and advancement are disappearing. Managers are unwilling to listen to proactive ideas to appease regional vertical "leadership".

job_title: Middle Management in Green Bay, WI
pros: You can advance rapidly if you are willing to pledge allegiance to the company flag.  Be a good employee, make a name for yourself and you can move forward.
cons: The higher you get within the corporation, the more you realize the actual corporate values.  #1 value is to turn a profit, NOT to change lives like they like to say.  Upper management likes to change for the sake of change rather than because it's what best for students. The whole organization has no clue what it's doing, it's like upper management is just guessing what is going to work without listening to people who actually know what's going on.  The constant refusal to upgrade pay of adjunct instructors is EMBARRASSING.

review_title: Crash course in learning what not to do & where not to be
pros:
- met some great people (colleagues) who are in the same boat as you
- access to a lot of free food on a regular basis
cons:
- micro management by supervisors
- you will get random titles but you will work on something completely different. Lot of work. And get paid according to what title you get not your skill set. They cheat you from day 1.
- Consultants are given more importance than full time employees.
- no sense of oneness in the teams. 
- no opportunity to grow as a professional. You are pretty much told what to do. Anything beyond that is "you need to be coached by your supervisor". They treat you like high school kids.
- all over the place. Mgmt doesn't know what they are doing, what they are supposed to do 
- the only way to get promoted is if you bond with the "right" people. 
- Performance based incentives  or even appreciation is a dream here. If you are sincere - please find another place to work at.
- no annual increments based on performance (neither yours nor the company)
I could keep writing but if you think you need more after reading above... I guess you should be fine working here then.
I haven't met even a single person so far who has positives to say for this place. None.

review_title: All the criticism of for-profit colleges is manifested at Rasmussen College
job_title: Middle Management in Oak Brook, IL
pros: It's a good stepping stone if you're new to the field of higher education. If you gain experience here you can get a 'real' higher education job elsewhere. But unless you're senior management, you won't likely last long here. Either you'll be burned out or you'll be forced to move along if you have integrity and start to question the status quo. If you can fall in line and turn off your ethics, though, you can have a long career here. The college is run by a handful of people who are making money hand over fist while pretending to 'help' people. It's all about making money. And the president is nothing but a figurehead, the college is run by a corporation and they just keep her to appear to have ties to the past.
cons: It's a business, not a school, and it's run that way. The only thing that matters is the bottom line. There is no loyalty to employees yet they expect loyalty from employees. Leadership knows nothing about education--they hire people from chain stores and rental car companies with management experience to run campuses.

review_title: Rasmussen is a good, growing company with good employees that is experiencing a few growing pains.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oak Brook, IL
pros: Overall a good, positive group of people.  Benefits are really good for full time employees (I was not one of them). The company seems to trust the people working for them which allows people to feel comfortable suggesting good ideas/improvements & those ideas being heard.
cons:
Oak Brook is not a fun place to commute to if you live in Chicago, especially closer to the lake.  If that's the case plan on at least 2 hours of driving (round-trip) each day.

Environment is a little sterile.  Very corporate, which is to be expected with a company this size.

pros:
Flexible schedule open 7 days a week from 8am to 9pm can adjust hours as needed within reason. 

Can work weekends and take the following days off as a result. Nice to help save vacation days or when you are going on a long trip (work the weekend before) take 2 days off the following week without using PTO. 

Pretty good annual raise (above national average for inflation).
cons:
Have to work weekends once in awhile. 

Directors micro manage you. 

Last raise was $1,500 less than what was expected and was only told to us 1 month before the reviews were due. 

Have to wear dress pants and dress shirt despite have no interaction with students in the online division.

Have to clock in and out like a blue collar job despite have bachelor's degree's or higher.

review_title: Overall positive, but you might be left feeling over worked and under appreciated.
pros: Fast paced, nice and friendly people, great benefits (several weeks vacation, paid holidays, 401K, partially paid maternity leave), flexible schedule (most managers/positions)
cons: Little professional development.  Instead of preparing their current employees for advancement they hire externally and therefore employees that have been with the organization for many years find it hard to advance.  It is easy to get burnt out... if you give them an inch, they will take a mile.  Pay structure is not organized; employees with the same title could have 20K+ difference in salary.

review_title: Toxic, catty, and you'll be fired before you decide to leave.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oak Brook, IL
pros: It used to be a great, youthful culture with respect for its employees.  That has taken a sharp decline over the last 2 years.  No more employee appreciation, slashed anything that could save a penny, no job security or promotions from within.
cons: It's a sinking ship.  When you interview, you'll be sold a happy bill of goods but you'll know the truth soon enough after you start.  The volume of people who are hired and fired is simply staggering.  And when someone goes, the workload is just assumed by those left behind.  Work more, no salary increase. No one lasts long. NO ONE from worker bees to management.  The College has expanded and contracted so many times, changed policies, rebranded, opened and closed departments, it's as if the leadership doesn't have a clue as its making the mad dash for that for-profit educational dollar.  Working in the corporate office, it's almost impossible to detect that you're connected to a college but I guess that says something about for-profit "education."

job_title: Student Finance Advisor in Brooklyn Park, MN
pros: The people at the campus level are great.  The work itself is okay, but not very challenging.  It's a fun environment if you are a recent college grad looking for your first "real" job.
cons: Not a lot of room for movement outside of your department.  Rasmussen overworks their employees without providing overtime and with no real way of tracking comp time, so it's easy to work and not get paid.  While they say they encourage a work-life balance, they really don't.  Each employee is expected to work one late night per week, even if they don't have childcare for that night.  Management also tends to back up the students more than their own employees.

pros: A good place to go if you want to get some experience in higher education, and use that experience to leave (or get fired) and move on to a job at a REAL college instead of a for-profit, make-believe college. There are some genuinely good people who work here that mean well and try to help students, but they are hamstrung by poor leadership and worse policies.
cons: Management is clueless when it comes to education and motivated by their own little agendas and profits, not the benefit of the students. Every level of management is a continuous revolving door, except a few key people who are running it like it's their own private playground. Anyone who speaks out even a little about poor executive decisions is accused of insubordination and usually terminated. The college has made HUGE profits year-in and year-out and claims it can't afford pay raises. Well, someone's making money hand-over-fist. It isn't the employees.

review_title: It seemed ok. (interview review only) didn't work here.
pros:
-Everyone who worked there was upbeat and easy to talk to.
-Easy interviews.
-Nice building.
cons:
-Refused to tell me the salary when I asked in both interviews. They ran around the question saying, 'Well, what do you think your worth?" So I said, "What would you pay someone with my qualifications?" It was a cat/mouse game and I never received an answer. 
-The 2 women in charge of this entire company is who I interviewed with in the 2nd and final step and both of them tried talking me out of taking the Admissions Rep position because I had an outgoing personality and they kept asking, "Do you really think you'd be ok with a desk job?"
-They offered to give me a tour, I said yes, and then they never gave the tour.
-The position was available due to management/policy changes
-High turn over rate.
-Took forever to deny me the position. I had to email to get an answer.

pros: Working with students, feeling like you are helping the community, beautiful facilities, OK benefits, fast-paced, etc.
cons: Things are constantly changing (which isn't bad when changes are consistent and yield results), work flow and pay are not congruent -- you will be overworked and overpaid --at least I was. After I left, I found out that others in my position were making 25%-65% more than me when I had equal to more education, experience, and outperformed them. It was heart-breaking to know that I loved my job and the work I did but the management I loved didn't value me the same. Once morale started dropping, turn-over increased, advancement options decreased, and politics took over, it was easy to leave.

review_title: Great faculty and staff, but unstable leadership
pros: Student and faculty interaction is strong, community involvement is positive, and professional relationships last a lifetime. On the campus level, people still care.
cons:
Compared to industry average, many are underpaid with no hope of promising pay increases. Workload can be daunting and mundane without true direction. Corporate leadership is constantly making changes without true expertise to validate those changes. Salaries are only great for those with close ties to the corporate offices, close friends or family of executives, or grandfathered salary. 

A huge disparity in pay between corporate and nursing leadership versus the rest of academic affairs that possess equal or more advanced credentials. Stagnate program, leadership with no connection to campus life where ultimate success is determined. Nepotism is rampant through the company and there is no objectivity between HR and leadership

review_title: Think Twice About Working in Admissions
pros: Good Benefits, Masters Degree Tuition Reimbursement, 40 hours/week job for Admissions.
cons: Awful Management, Micromanaging, Office Politics, Cattiness, etc. Low performers get the same raise as the highest performer. No bonuses. Have to work weekends in admissions. Furthermore, admissions is forced to work until 9pm during the week. Middle Management are often brought in from outside the company and therefore have never done the job of the employees that he/she are managing.

pros: This position allows me to further enhance my mentoring skills, which provides me with skills needed in the health administrative environment, while allowing me to assist others in developing needed critical thinking skills. This position also provides me with the training needed to obtain my certification as a NCLCA Certified Learning Center Professional.
cons: This is currently a part time position through a work-study program. While mentoring is a passion for me, it is not a position that will allow me to provide for my family at this time.

review_title: Wonderful culture of talented individuals focused on supporting students in anyway possible.
pros:
Wonderful culture with a positive attitude.
Many opportunities within the organization to learn and grow.
Great people to work with and tremendous student body.
cons:
No clearly defined path to management.
Training program needs a fresh take and more personalized to positions and individuals.
Performance reviews are holistic and don't focus on the individual.

review_title: They talk a good game but won't improve operations.
job_title: Systems Engineer in Burr Ridge, IL
pros: They managed to pick some excellent people to bring into operations and everyone in the Operations team was top notch, professional and had come from great environments with a great deal of experience.
cons: Existing management is completely incompetent and is unable to pivot in order to improve the environment.  They hired a Director of Operations that came from a much larger company, with a wealth of experience who was looking to build a top flight operations team and they wouldn't give him the control needed to run and managed to get him to walk away.  There has been no day-to-day director of operations for five months.

pros: Innovative approach to higher education. Flexible work schedule and we were allowed to work from home which was nice. Nice campus facility which had new equipment and was very clean.
cons: High turnover. Colleagues were poorly qualified for the positions they held.  Lots of micromanaging and stifling amount of oversight, no autonomy or decision making power. Was nothing more than a figurehead.

review_title: In a word Horrible. everyone treats you like dirt
job_title: Online Instructor in New York, NY
pros: Sorry but there are none.
cons:
1.Training after instructing employment start-
2. compensation doesn't meet job requirements-- your stated compensation is higher than I was paid -- 
3. students are not prepared for class-- prerequisites are inappropriate -- should be classed with Westwood-- students insult instructors -- 1 student in class of 30 makes the grade-- 30% of students in  class do the work on time --
4. students do not work independently and expect instructor to spoon feed them ALL of the answers-- 
5. employees are expected to exert effort 4 times more than should be necessary--
6.  50%  more administrators and middle level educators than necessary--

pros: Being a peer tutor not only helps other students, it helps the tutor themselves. Tutoring offers a flexible work schedule that understands education comes first. It helps tutors grow in their personal development, such as expanding on communication skills, time management skills, self reflection, as well as build a deeper understanding of the topics covered. The teams are wonderful and incredibly supportive, as are the managers. Your work feels truly appreciated.
cons: It is work study, so the highest number of hours you can get a week are 29. There is also a two week period between semesters where you won't receive work/pay.

review_title: The Program Manager position has an extremely high burnout rate.
pros: I started out at an above average salary because of my past experience and was able to increase my salary by 16% in two years. The health insurance provided by Rasmussen was above average.
cons: Jobs are constantly threatened. Its all about hitting a number and if you miss your number you are treated like scum of the earth. I was constantly discouraged from taking my vacation time because it would take away time for me to enroll students.

review_title: Are you good at car sales? Want to treat college like car sales?? This is for you!
pros: Benefits, pay, the other PMs were great to work with. But none of it was enough to make me stay.
cons: Depending on the director you have it can be okay or it can burn you out. I realized the company keeps the PM with a student until we get their money, after that the PM disappears. I could not ethically continue knowing we get their trust just to get their money.

review_title: Great Culture/Continuously Strives for Positive Change and Leadership within the Industry
job_title: Student Records Coordinator in Bloomington, MN
pros: Rasmussen College has great leadership, work atmosphere, and respects the work/life balance. The organization values diversity in its leadership, and continuously strives for positive change in order to exceed industry standards. It puts student success first, and is constantly evaluating and implementing changes that will benefit students and student success in the ever-changing job market.
cons: Opportunities for promotions and growth in the company seem confusing and few and far between. No real clear path of how to get from point A to point B. Getting answers to HR related questions (HR based out of Illinois) can be a struggle.

job_title: Program Manager in Brooklyn Park, MN
pros: It's a good place to get sales experience or experience in the higher education industry if you're a young professional.
cons: Management clearly played favorites.  Sometimes goals were unrealistic (making a decent raise nearly impossible).  Even if the college wasn't the best option for a student (seeing as most colleges offer a better reputation at a lower price), we were told to sell, sell, sell and do what it took to get our students to come to Rasmussen.

review_title: Loved my job until corporate team made questionable choices
pros:
- Working directly with students in the admissions process was rewarding
- Flexible hours
- Incentive programs
- Team-building and camaraderie across departments
- LOCAL campus leadership was ethical and proved to be wonderful mentors
cons:
- CORPORATE leadership proved to be unethical and all about the money
- Financial aid officers were eliminated so admissions personnel took it over, which is a conflict of interest
- Values are about making money not providing a quality education
- Very demotivating to see students drop out left and right while racking up big student loans
- Fellow admissions teammates were often catty and cliquey.

review_title: I have been working at Rasmussen College full-time for more than 3 years
job_title: Learning Management Systems Administrator in Oak Brook, IL
pros: Pros – Student and faculty interaction is strong, community involvement is positive, and professional relationships last a lifetime. Employees in the Corporate Office are great people and probably will become life long friends, because we share a ton in common. Hard workers and willing to go the extra mile.
cons:
Cons – Compared to industry average, many are underpaid with no hope of promising pay increases. Workload can be daunting and mundane without true direction. Corporate leadership is constantly making changes without true expertise to validate those changes. Salaries are only great for those with close ties to the corporate offices, close friends or family of executives, or grandfathered salary.

A huge disparity in pay between corporate and nursing leadership versus the rest of academic affairs that possess equal or more advanced credentials. Stagnate program, leadership with no connection to campus life where ultimate success is determined. Nepotism is rampant through the company and there is no objectivity between HR and leadership

Most employees feel like there is no road map from position to position. 2%-25% yearly Increases that's ludicrous who deserves a 2% increase (that's a slap in the face) - and How in the hell do you get a 25% increase - I received a promotion took on extra projects and received less of an increase as I gave my direct report (WTF). Unless you are working on an important or visible project you are just status quo - your direct reporting manager doesn't know strengths and there aren't many opportunities to show your talents

pros:
Pay was pretty good
Benefits were great
Free education
cons:
No chance of advancement
Promotions to Admissions managers or SR. Program Manager were only monetary. You were still telemarketing. 
THIS IS A TELEMARKETING JOB! Leads are warm, but still not very good.
DOAs and Upper Management Positions were all filled with outside candidates
If you are looking for a job that you will grow professionally, THIS IS NOT IT!!!!

pros: Growing company, one of the major players in the online education industry, very likely to go public in a few years, young management team, comfortable work environment, tuition reimbursement, free caffeinated beverages, 2 weeks vacation, health benefits including fsa
cons: growing quickly and losing some of the company culture, small company becoming very corporate very quickly, long hours, expectation to work tremendous amounts of overtime and on holidays

pros: Fast paced, corporate structure allowed for a variation in work activities from day to day.  Opportunities for payment for performance based upon the number of students brought in for each start.
cons: Economy greatly affects sales.  With such volatility in the work environment, at times it could be a challenge to recruit new students to the college.  There is much attention paid to meeting the sales numbers, and students are looked at as revenue vs. people.

pros:
- VP and C-level leadership are rotated out very quickly in the technology department
- Vague, irrelevant requirements for positions allow for uneducated, inexperienced people to excel: for example, some members of leadership have held only a B.S. degree while they require a Master's to teach courses in technology
cons:
- Vague, irrelevant requirements for positions allow for uneducated, inexperienced people to excel
- Unclear direction
- Technology decisions made behind closed doors under socio-political agendas rather than real customer requirements (for example, <Fictional Bob> has researched product X and even though it meets none of the requirements we choose Product X because we like <Fictional Bob>)

pros: The people to my left and right were awesome. Most of us were overqualified, energetic, and student focused.
cons: Employee attrition rates are sky high and the interview process is a waste of time. Takes months to hire someone new and days for people to quit. x

review_title: If you can weather the constant changes...
pros: Friendly staff, employee development. Unlike some other for-profit schools Rasmussen has ethical standards about which students they admit and will be honest with those that are unlikely to succeed.
cons:
Corporate structure and re-organizations seem to
be a constant. While some moves come across as proactive many times drastic changes will happen with little to no notice.

review_title: A great company that encouraged continued education and personal development.
job_title: Assistant to the Deans in Rockford, IL
pros: Rasmussen had an amazing group of positive people working there that always encouraged each other and helped one another to succeed. There was also a high degree of professionalism which projected onto the students as well.
cons: Some corporate politics here and there.

pros: Great place to start your career.  The people you work with are fun and out going.
cons: "Sales" job pressures without the compensation.  Upper management has not caught up with the "times" as far as motivating their employees without the bonuses. or $$.  Not very many options to move up within Admissions.  Expected to work nights, weekends and holidays.

review_title: Work here only if you want to use your benefits for anxiety medication
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Tampa, FL
pros: Hours, salary and a few genuine employees
cons: Work demands are unrealistic and employees are constantly compared against each other. The job shames and threatens employees into being successful. It is a sales job, so make no mistake.

job_title: Financial Aid Officer in Eagan, MN
pros: Coworkers are fantastic. Benefits are super good including, vision and dental. Three weeks of vacation and unlimited sick days. Flexible hours, work whenever you want as long as you get your 40 hours in.
cons: Pay isn't great and raises come once a year at a set rate. Not a lot of room to advance. Not great communication from the top down.

job_title: Student Finance Officer in Ocala, FL
pros: Good benefits. Wonderful people to work with
cons: Way too many useless and unproductive meetings.  Management wants multiple things done at the same time and expect nothing to fall through the cracks. Required to chase after grown people to come to class.  Recruit people to come to "college" and get a degree in a field that only pays $9.00/hr but they have $22,000 in debt.

review_title: Great culture and product in a challenging industry.
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Rasmussen hires and promotes well, resulting in a positive and supportive culture. Their reputation and accreditation stands out against competitors. Compensation and annual salary increases above industry standards. Lots of respect for work/life balance.
cons: For-profit education is a troubled industry. While Rasmussen is better than most at confronting competitive and regulatory challenges, long-term success in this industry is in question.

job_title: Fed Work Study In Financial Aid in Ocala, FL
pros: Everyone is very helpful, they show you new things and how to do them. Most of them have open door policies so you can ask them anything.
cons: I have a long drive. Even on breaks between quarters I am still at school since I work there.

review_title: The current stage of growth at Rasmussen provided opportunity for hands on, experience-based career development.
pros: Good place for hands on career development.
cons: Company is trapped technically with many hands-on processes that are tedious and draining time-wise and prone to misinterpretation and error.

pros: Higher pay and somewhat flexible schedule. On average, 4 days a week working on site or at clinicals. You definitely put in the extra hours at home though.
cons: Scheduling is a nightmare as this is done by the instructors rather than another hired staff member. Its a 50/hr a week job all said and done.

pros: People on the front lines are great! Hard working and talented. They are truly student focused.
cons:
Excessive nepotism. People are not promoted based on skills and talent.  

Executive leadership has little grasp on the effects of their decisions or simply does not care. Actions speak louder than words.

pros: Rasmussen College is a leader in education that puts a strong focus on their commitment to students. I have enjoyed making professional relationships, that will last a lifetime.
cons: I do not have cons of working for Rasmussen College, aside from occasionally having to sit at a desk. Stand up desks would be nice!

pros:
I've gotten to know a lot of really great people. Most of them work here anymore, but I guess there's that. Most of the people I know who've left the school have left the industry altogether. 

I was able to spend most of my time here working from home, but many of my counterparts at other campuses are not that lucky, being dragged in for a constant stream of irrelevant and repetitive meetings so the campus director can check of some bullet point on their job description.

I was able to work with relative autonomy while looking for new opportunities.

Pay is on the low end for full-time instructors, but even worse for adjunct instructors. The benefits were reasonable.
cons:
New initiatives and "pilot" programs that never go anywhere. I understand they are attempting to innovate by trying different ideas, but history shows a real lack of vision and foresight.

Most promotions are in name only, or to backfill the latest layoffs. 

Basic concepts like management hierarchy and department names are in constant flux. There are new supervisors every 6 months or so. Musical department chairs. 

There is no career path for instructors that involves meaningful compensation, only a change in title. I usually work about 3 jobs including this one to pay bills.

Admissions is pure sales without the bonuses. Students are regularly referred to as "customers". If you're trying to shake the negative for-profit reputation this has to go. 

Moving all programs to 5.5 week "self-paced" terms, which amounts to a lot of meaningless assignments and poor student performance. But, hey, money.

Lack of academic rigor in the courses, and lack of flexibility to make meaningful changes to the online courses. Irrelevant discussion posts, unclear assignments, and unquantifiable outcomes are the norm rather than the exception.

pros: Work environment is great. Employees work hard and care about their performance. Lot of respect for work life balance.The compensation and benefits are competitive.
cons: There is a lack of direction and communication from leadership, partly due to being a start up company. There is also lack of training in place,

pros: Great people to work with, good benefits
cons: High work-load, salary lower than average industry salary, ability to work flexible hours varies significantly across the departments, depending on who you report to (rather than a college-wide policy); top-heavy organization; lack of development and almost non-existent bonus structure for the lower level employees/ lower management; frequent turnover in IT department

pros: At the Fargo and Moorhead campuses, the atmosphere and people are always so nice and very easy to get along with.  I work as a student ambassador and they work around my schedule and will do anything for me if needed.  They seem to actually care about everyone around.
cons: I do not have any cons with the time I have been here.

job_title: Director of Student Affairs in Appleton, WI
pros:
Student Success is top priority.  
Proprietary College that cares about students, financial obligations and placement
Offers scholarships to employees for education
Collaboration among campuses
cons:
Economy has caused a slow down in hiring staff leaving those already hired to do many jobs
Many manual processes that could be upgraded.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in Hanover Park, IL
pros: Everyone is friendly and happy to help you out when you don't understand what to do.
cons: The hours are based on your Federal work study position which makes it hard because some get full 20 hours as part time and some don't.

pros: Sick days. You can take paid sick days. That’s the only good thing about working here.
cons:
- they only care about money 
- undervalue employees, treated like pawns 
- micromanaging 
- no teamwork 
- degree mill, they don’t value education. They refer themselves as a company in the office, but a “college” when creditors are present.

job_title: Network Administrator Work Study in New Port Richey, FL
pros: Family Atmosphere, Great flexibility for scheduling, Great Work and Family Programs, All around great place to work
cons: I've been employed here for almost two years and I have loved every second of it. So if your asking me for a con about this employer I really can't find one.

job_title: STUDENT ENGAGEMENT REPRESENTATIVE/NURSING ACCOUNT MANAGER in Minneapolis, MN
pros: If you care about education and changing the lives of students looking for their golden ticket then this is the place for you. Campuses are condensed and easy to navigate.
cons: The lack of direction for employees looking to advance. Most advancement opportunities are in title only with salary raises predetermined. Pay, lack of advancement opportunities, weekend work is required.

job_title: Online Adjunct Instructor in Minneapolis, MN
pros: easy to acquire employment if you have a master's degree in your field
cons: low pay, $1500 per 11 wk course regardless of education and experience, hours and hours of grading and little time for real contact with students, no control for plagiarism or cheating among students, courses are supposed to be capped at 25 students but are often overloaded with no increase in pay

pros: I loved my boss, my work, and colleagues. One of the best work experiences I have every had! It was fast paced with change the norm, but I went into the job expecting this.
cons: Work-life balance was a challenge as I was part of a start-up operation and intentionally worked long hours.

job_title: Student Records Specialist in Wausau, WI
pros: Great group of people to work with on a campus level. Hours are flexible.
cons: Pay needs to be more competitive, cannot advance within the company unless able to relocate to the twin cities or Chicago.

pros: Pick your own shift, work from home, great peers to lead the way
cons: non in my position it was really a great job and opportunity and would still be doing it if I were enrolled

pros: Co-workers are generally great to work with
cons:
Compensation is a joke - don't expect more than a 1-2% raise, this on top of below industry salaries to start
"innovation" without structure
Constant turnover

pros: If you are lucky enough to be in a leadership position, the pay is good
cons: Unfortunately the money is spent hiring incompetent people who make poor decisions.

pros: Worked here for almost 2 years. Flexible hours. Friendly staff and faculty. Everyone has a positive attitude. Do your job and life will be easy.
cons: There is not much I can say as far as the cons of working here.

review_title: Great company that focuses on student success
pros: Fantastic people, great industry with an eye on student success.  A solid culture and stands behind it's values.
cons: Limited growth in certain locations. Career path somewhat undefined. Untapped resources within the organization.

pros: The best thing about this company is the pay scale.
cons: Lack of Management skills by Directors, Invisible Silos between departments,

review_title: Overall a decent job but not a good choice for a long term career
job_title: Student Finance Officer in Bloomington, MN
pros: flexible and family friendly, supportive work situation
cons: raises are minimal and don't reward employees who are better performers, so little incentive to go the extra mile.

review_title: I love being part of helping others being lifelong learners
pros: I love working at the school because it allows me the chance to network and meet others working towards the same degree and career goals.
cons: Not getting a break between tutor appointments.

job_title: Academic Dean in Lake Elmo, MN
pros: Great people to work with--hardworking and motivated to support others.
cons: Each salaried person works the job of at least 2 people. No work life balance.

pros: The College had a great beginning and the ethics and teaching principles were sound.
cons: Once the College went to a more corporate structure, the quality of education went down.

job_title: Senior Admissions Advisor in Bloomington, MN
pros: work life balance, nice people, employee appreciation
cons: Upper Management only sees numbers, secretive, lots of dialing, repetitive days

job_title: Accounting Intern in Oakbrook Terrace, IL
pros:
-Small close knit atmosphere
-Great experience, well rounded
-Didn't feel like an outsider
cons:
-Not much room for advancement
-Very difficult deadlines
-Staff is stretched to their limit

review_title: The people were very nice to work with but it is strictly a sales position
pros: Working with a great crowd of people
cons: High turn over rate, mainly cold call sales

review_title: Extremely low pay. Less than half that of competitors
job_title: Online Instructor in Oak Park, IL
pros: Getting to work from home. Can choose which hours of the day to work.
cons: Pays $9-11 per hour for someone with 20 years in her field and a master's degree. Working in my field I get $35-45 an hour.

job_title: Academic Dean in Lake Elmo, MN
pros: Rasmussen provides a collaborative work environment in which employee feedback and contributions are valued. I had the opportunity to work with many great people and felt consistently supported by leadership.
cons: No significant cons to note.

pros: Flexible schedules, good benefits, great people
cons: minimal training. Lack of ability to move up within the company

pros: The staff I work with truly care about the students well being and success.  State of the art online teaching.
cons: Pay is far below competitor salary for faculty.

pros: Great learning experience. Chance to be a leader within your team.
cons: Bad hours. Weekends. Not as flexible as the claim about time off.

pros: You get to work on your own time, help out other students in need, and have the income to pay for college.
cons: None that I can come up with

pros: The employees are team oriented & you are treated like an equal by everyone.
cons: There are really none that I can think of.

job_title: Student Ambassador in New Port Richey, FL
pros: Work around school schedule, allows time to study and do homework in between work. Easy going atmosphere.
cons: Only can work if you qualify through financial aid.

pros: Plenty of opportunities for those who like to work hard and those who can adapt well to change.
cons: You will do a hundred new things every day.

pros: Fast paced organization with plenty of opportunities to advance.
cons: constant turn over in executive management.  Very little continuing training opportunities.  Very poor work/life balance.

pros: Student interactions, love to teach.
cons: Pay was lousy, management was unavailable. High turnover. Poor work environment. Wouldn't know schedule until last minute.

review_title: It was ok place to work
pros:
Fast paced environment
Good people to work with
Working with students is the best part of the job

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Oak Brook, IL
pros: The online work is challenging and interesting.  I can work based on my hours that are available.
cons: There is not enough work each term.

pros: pay out bonus as agreed, co-workers are amazing, HQ by highway so easy commute, free online education and other perks.
cons: unreasonable executive management, always keep you on your toes, Exec do not respect basic needs of others as work life balance, exec management operates as if they are  own you and your entire being.

pros: Instructor independence and good academic program.

pros: Great people and teams.  Truly passionate about what they do.

pros: Friendly atmosphere and great leadership.

pros: Great communication and friendly environment!

review_title: Very good company, good benefits and a strong atmosphere of community.

cons: Always tweaking formula for work.

pros: culture , and the people make the difference

pros: Co Workers were great to work with.
